title: Do you regret studying psychology? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t regret studying psychology because the knowledge I gained has helped me understand others and has thus enriched my life. However, if you study psychology without giving thought to specific practical applications and goals, as I did, there is a real risk of finding yourself going nowhere. Depending on what you specialize in, you might also have to face consequences of studying such a popular field. In yet another way, I realize I might’ve been better served by choosing a different path. For those with careers in psychology and don’t understand what I’m about to say, it might be because your worldview already matches those of most others who study psychology or the social sciences in general - much like the way fish don’t notice the water around them. However, as a forewarning to those yet to find themselves in my current position, the field of psychology (and the social sciences in general) tend to be monolithic in terms of political ideology. I’ve experienced this firsthand. This never bothered me (as a member of the minority) until people in workplaces seemed to become vocally pushier in the past decade or so, roughly speaking. I personally conducted a pilot survey study on this. Simply put, in more recent times, I haven’t been able to work anywhere within this field (or within social sciences generally) without having co-workers yapping my ear off about politics, their political values, or trying to subtly find out what mine are (i.e., trying to “connect over ‘our’ values”). which, by the way, all goes against my culture of origin’s norms of social etiquette.

I’ve studied aspects of psychology independently for years until I pursued it in college. I’ve always been interested in the human mind. My other dream job was to become a veterinarian. But, I ended up choosing to pursue psychology of people as an undergraduate and beyond. I noticed that it was so easy for me to focus on human behavior. If you hold a high degree in psychology, the research aspect grows. Some experiments that have been completed and government funded can’t be replicated. That means the information that we believe in, and base new research on, may be false. There are statistical methods involved, grants, review boards involved in the institution where you work and outside of it. You can lose your license if you don’t take proper steps to ensure your study meets standard protocol. You’d be expected to share your results and get back moderate or excessive criticism. Your work can be flat out rejected otherwise. I know that my ultimate goal is to become a psychiatrist, which is someone who administers medication for disorders. They are also interested in the human mind. I am happy that I learned about psychology because both disciplines deal with human behavior and research. I don’t regret studying it.

Never. I studied psychology because I wanted to write when I was in college, and I felt that learning about people would help my characters. I also wanted to know more about myself. I took psychology as a minor but I was only one class short of a triple major. I thought about going into the field, but I decided I would rather be the star of my own life than the supporting cast in someone else's life. So many people are so money and career oriented, especially in my generation, GenX. But I have found my happiness and purpose through experiences. I savor life, and psychology has given me a solid foundation for understanding people and most importantly myself. It gives me a strange sense of calm in the face of other's anger, or facing stressful situations. I feel fearless. I know you make your own moods, happiness is a choice you can consciously make. Some moods are just chemicals. And there is no purpose in beating yourself up when there are millions out there ready to do it for you. And most importantly, you can only change yourself and your own behavior. You can nudge others towards the truth but you can never make them change because of it.

Well, I do regret taking psychology as one of the subjects to graduate that too from a government college. Not because I don't have any interest in it, but because of the faculty. I'm in my 2nd year of graduation and 4th sem as of now. Here we have 3 lady professors in psychology department. One of whom is pursuing her PhD and doesn't even teach any thing, let's call her ‘A’ A comes, read the notes from her phone, take attendance and leave. She doesn't even engage the students and is biased towards the students who doesn't go behind her at beck and call. Once in a while she asks our opinions, even after that she says we are wrong. And from the 1st sem she is the one who is taking our classes and now we are bored of her. We have a class of one hour. She comes after 15 minutes and leaves before 10 minutes. Even after being through in my subject and answers during exam she gives only 8 GPA and her fans gets 10. I'm quite fed up. Can't even complain against her as our marks, internal(midsem) and semends are in her hand. We have to maintain a record of the surveys we do. Notes are dictated by her in the class. She can't send the pictures of them in the WhatsApp group as it's not the way ‘teachers behave.’ Have to attend the classes regularly to main 75% attendance rule or else she may detain us in the semends as well as pay the condonation fees. 3 down 3 more to go. I'm sure she is the only one who is going to take the classes for whole graduation. I believe teachers make the subject interesting not the other way around. Education in India is becoming like: Attend the classes, study on your own, write the exams, pass the subject and move on with less to nil practical knowledge. God only knows how I'll graduate with only bookish theoretical knowledge in psychology and no practical knowledge.

Every once in a while. People can be hypochondriacs with mental illnesses as much as they can be with physical ones. I originally started my quest for a degree in psychology because I knew something was wrong with me. I just didn’t know what. So I would read about these disorders in textbooks and think, “OMG! That sounds JUST! LIKE! ME!” Aside from that, I know it’s really important to have a certain measure of self-awareness in order to change. Dr. Phil says something like “You can’t change what you don’t acknowledge.” I tend to think of this like a blind man wearing a purple shirt and red pants. He can’t change his clothes to match better because he can’t see what’s going on. But the level of self-awareness I have, in part because of my knowledge psychology, is soooo very frustrating at times. I know I suffer from depression. I know why I suffer from depression. But I can’t change it. I should be able to change it. Same with anxiety and panic disorder. I understand so much about myself and the psychology of my illnesses, and yet… I have been unable to change these things about myself. Thank you for the A2A, Michael.

I don’t, at least not yet. The majority of classes I took focused on childhood development and developmental psychology. I now work with children and I feel that what I have learned has greatly assisted me in being able to communicate with children in a way that they understand and facilitates learning and growth. I also have used my studies to assist my personal life as I have diagnosed depression and anxiety, both of which I now self-treat as I have made changes to my life to be less stressed and I no longer live in a mentally abusive environment. Granted I do not have my Masters or PhD, so psychology-based jobs are mostly off the table, but it has assisted me in my career and life so far.

I have done psychology as my specialization during my graduation so I can safely answer this question. I don't regret doing psychology at all. In fact I love it so much I keep telling everyone about it. I have learnt so much from this subject , I have learnt to look at things from a different perspective. I studied Psychology because I had love for this subject not because I was looking to make a career in it. Also, I love the reaction that people give me when I tell them I have studied psychology . They immediately want me to read their mind and study their behavior. I would suggest you take it up only if you like it, its not everyone's cup of tea.

Hell no. Knowing how to read people is an invaluable skill/tool. Being about to predict behaviour, to some extent, in a given circumstance has saved me a lot of time, money and frustration. The use of psychological methods and recommendations has allowed me to put newly met people at ease quickly, make friends, get tasks done faster and increase employee satisfaction in a workplace with minimal effort on my part. The more I know about why humans do the things they do, the more I want to know. It’s a field that provides instant results when applied correctly. And you can refine your method of application for the rest of your life.

Yes and no. Psychology is a very useful subject to know, and it's extremely interesting. However, for most people (including me, with excellent grades) it's a dead end. Most people won't find jobs related to psychology and most people who hire for other jobs don't give a shit if you have it on your resumé. In other words, only study psychology if you are positive you'll get a job with it, or if you can afford getting another education in addition to it. Otherwise it's a waste of time and money.

No however I never thought about going into the field, but I decided I would rather be the star of my own life than the supporting cast in someone else's life only with regards my personal relationships. My choice was to apply the skill as a business owner…it has been rewarding that a traditional career would not have been for me. Nearly every CEO I have worked with wished they had studied psychology…it compliments so much.

Q: Do you regret studying psychology? Not even a little bit. It’s been immensely useful, even though I ended up on another career path in the long run. But recently I’ve been able to refresh my knowledge, and it’s coming in handy for my new hobby-maybe-more (game development). I’ve kept reading about a variety of psychological areas of interest beyond my original field of study throughout my life, and it’s all been fascinating as well as useful.

One thing I regret studying psychology is that I didn’t study more of it. My life has changed the day I know that our emotions and behavior are understandable and explainable. We are, the human, are the most beautiful creature in the world/universe, and our psychology is a big part of it. There is nothing more awesome than to know and to understand about it.

Definitely not. I was a Finance major undergrad and then earned a Masters in Real Estate Finance. I am currently working towards a Master of Applied Positive Psychology and couldn’t be happier. The more I learn about psychology, the more I realize everything else is based off of this field - at it’s core, it is the scientific study of the mind and human behavior. Go for it! Sharon

No. In fact, just by learning psychology, I can help myself to connect psychology to other aspects of our life such as human body language, why people do certain things, etc. and lead me to the answer I’m looking for. I may not be studying psychology for the sake of getting a job for it, but at least I can further understand human beings a little more to accompany me along with what I intend to do in the future.

No,I do not regret studying psychology,as a person who deals with mental health issues it help save my life. The people who have help me also saved my life,their efforts keep me from leaving my wife and 2 sons with nothing. If you need help there are people who care and will help. Never give in to death. Life is too short anyway. Yours,Keith v Lewis

Abso-FREAKING-lutely, especially after graduating and trying to pass these damn tests, which you have to pay for every retake. Not to mention the job market. Psychology has been the worst thing that has ever happened to me, so far.
